meanings.definition: To take something by force or theft.
meanings.sent1: The bandit reives the treasure from the unsuspecting travelers.
meanings.sent2: The thief reives valuable items from the store.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous raccoon reives shiny objects from the campsite.
meanings.sent4: The storm reives the leaves from the trees, scattering them across the yard.
meanings.sent5: The greedy pirate reives gold coins from the sunken ship.

meanings.sent1: Criminals often reives homes when the owners are away.
meanings.sent2: The invaders reives the village of its resources.
meanings.sent3: The sneaky cat reives treats from the kitchen counter.
meanings.sent4: Time reives our youth, leaving us with memories.
meanings.sent5: The vultures reives the carcass, leaving nothing behind.

meanings.definition: To seize or carry off forcibly.
meanings.sent1: The eagle reives the fish from the water with its sharp talons.
meanings.sent2: The kidnappers reives the child from the playground.
meanings.sent3: The vacuum cleaner reives the crumbs from the carpet.
meanings.sent4: The tornado reives the roof off the house, leaving it exposed.
meanings.sent5: The giant reives the tiny village from its place and carries it away.
